title.narrative: Energy Sector, India Off shore Wind Power

description.narrative: Energy Sector, India - OFf shore Wind Power (Phase 1) - Strategic Sector Cooperation

title.narrative: Development and implementation of coordinated measures for minimizing grid infrastructure and supply chain obstacles to the development of the offshore wind sector.
Progress on implementation of necessary measures for minimising grid infrastructure and supply chain obstacles to the development of the offshore wind sector while reducing risk to investors.

target.value: Progress on implementation of necessary measures

actual.value: 10 DEA visits to India and 4 delegation visits to Denmark to knowledge-share on tender documents, environmental impact assessments, geotechnical surveys and supply chain infrastructure development.

target.value: Centre of excellence has established a functioning convening forum for improvement of grid infrastructure and supply chain development for offshore wind and has facilitated its first event with stakeholder.

actual.value:
A forum has yet to be established. The process of establishing the forum is well under way with engagement from the Indian partners.
The establishment of the forum has been delayed mainly due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

target.value:
The programme does not have a formal target for 2022 (as it was initially planned to finalize by Nov 2021 but a 1-year no-cost extension was made due to COVID-19).
An informal target would be to further this dialogue forum and gain a coordinated and well-based idea of the necessary grid infrastructure measures to be made ready for the first offshore wind farms in India.

Centre of excellence has established a functioning convening forum for improvement of grid infrastructure and supply chain development for offshore wind and has facilitated its first event with stakeholder.

actual.value:
The Centre of Excellence was inaugurated by the Indian Minister of New and Renewable Energy & Power, R.K. Singh, and Danish Minister of Climate, Energy & Utilities, Dan Jørgensen, on 9th September 2021.
Following this, a dialogue forum between the relevant authorities (CEA, CERC, POSOCO, MNRE and CTU) has been established on grid planning for offshore wind.

title.narrative: Improved framework conditions for sustainable development

SSC contributions in 2019 to framework conditions within energy in India: "5 ".
Score from 1-5, 1 lowest and 5 highest.
The planned output targets in the project have been met in 2019.
Several activities were arranged in 2019; - Full implementation of SSC activities incl. successful 1st meeting in the Steering Committee. - Signing of SSC Cooperation agreement with MNRE - 17 Indian officials received DFC scholarships to participate in the four energy courses in Denmark - 1 research project given under Window 2 to DTU Wind: ” Maintenance and Repair Strategy for Wind Energy Development” (3 years, DKK 4,7 million) - 3 mobility grants given to Indian researchers for conducting research with Danish research institutions (Power system architecture for microgrids, Recycling of lithium-ion batteries for energy storage, Hybrid energy storage for smart community microgrid incl. EV charging) - 7 DEA visits to India and 4 delegations to Denmark.
An enabling framework that streamlines site selection, clearances and procurement while reducing risk to investors.
Progress on implementation of necessary measures for an enabling framework that streamlines site selection, clearances and procurement of offshore wind while reducing risk to investors

target.value: De-risking of procurement based on the lessons learned from the first tender and from Danish experiences can be verified in the Indian documentation

actual.value:
During 2021, the DEA shared best practises with MNRE on the early stage development of new offshore market with ambitious target. Moreover, the maritime spatial planning and 30 GW sites selection project for offshore wind in India have progressed during 2021 with an aim to finalize by mid-2022.
Lastly, DEA, MNRE and NIWE co-produced the first Indian technology catalogue for offshore wind and the LCOE report, which outlines the preliminary costs (LCOE) of offshore wind in India along with analyses of the key cost elements, sensitivity analyses and recommendations. This was furthered in the latter part of 2021 through a thorough investor dialogue to consolidate and de-risk the expected cost levels.

Initiated “Financial modelling of offshore wind in India” which aims to involve government, commercial, and research stakeholders in a dialogue-based process to make more accurate Levelised cost of energy estimations for offshore wind in India.

target.value: MNRE has published documentation for the first offshore auction in India where input from Danish experiences can be seen

actual.value: MNRE has yet to publish documentation for the first offshore auction. However, extensive engagement has been done on Danish experience with de-risking processes and tools with great Indian buy-in, by, amongst other things, building further upon the joint “Financial modelling of offshore wind in India” - project.

target.value:
The programme does not have a formal target for 2022 (as it was initially planned to finalize by Nov 2021 but a 1-year no-cost extension was made due to COVID-19).
Informal targets would be: - To share the latest Danish experiences within de-risking of procurement based on the Thor tender and how it can be used in an Indian context. - To finalize the maritime spatial planning and 30 GW site selection project (delayed in 2021 due to COVID-19). - To finalize and disseminate the second version of the LCOE and viability gap funding estimates of offshore wind in India.
